Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said.Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamersfor Marceille, Gibralter, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Saidafter the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindle Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before
The express steamer usually reaches Brindial on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving to London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindial or via Marseille.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or MArseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcotta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOB (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: The Sultan and The Powers
div.p: For the moment the tension that has been existing between the Sultan and the Powers is releived, and the Sublime Porte is state to have accepted the Macedonian financial scheme subjecct to numerous modifications. The crisis, it is hardly needful to point out, is only temporaryily releaved even if we assume that the Sultan's concessions are genuine, ffor the Macedonian problem will never be solved by the peaceful methods of diplomacy or such mild acts of coercion as the seizure of custom houses. The Blue Book issued yesterday week on the situation shows very clearly the disturbed state of the country, and gives information as to the steps taken by the Powers to bring about an improvement. Whether the measures that have been, and are now being taken will improved the position is quite a different matter; unfortunately there is not much room for hope that they will. The fault does not rest with the Sultan, as some agitators would have us believe. It is true, of course, that his honesty of the officials is seldom very conspicious; but the main difficulty is in the dissensions of the Christian. The creeds of the rival sects are still of that sturdy nature which disdains toleration: and accordingly the long list of Macedonian outbreaks contain many outrages and murders committed by one Christian body on the other, while the Turkish Government looks on, only occasionally interfering that it may impartially massacre both. Whille the Churches are strong enough to defy the Government and to play on the fanatic feelings of their followers by egging them on, and while the neighboring States are able to interfere and to stir up racial as well as religious strife, it is safe to predict that the condition of Macedonia will not be greatly ameliorated. The establishment of a strong Administration able to depress disorder severly, whether committed by Christian of Turk, seems to real way out; but at the moment it is not possible; and the other alternative suggested, that the country shall be divided among the disputants, would probably lead to open war.

div.head: The Kaiser's Speech
div.p: The German Emperor's speech at the opening of the new session of the Reichstag last week has aroused considerable attention throughout Europe. The speech was delivered to the members in person. This unusual proceddure might be expected to introduce some fresh programme to his people, and his words accordingly have been read with close attention at home and abroad. With regard to the financial proposals that were semi ofificially disclosed a fortnight ago the Kaiser has given no further information; and it may reasonably be concluded therefrom that they have been sufficiently well understood to need no comment from the Head of State. The situation in the colonies was touched on, and after a sympathetic reference to the troops in South West Africa, there is a promise that the Colonial Budgets will be simplified, as "the basis for a measure of colonial self government." the criticism made in Berlin that self government is hardly po+ssible until the colonies are self supporting will perhaps be revised onmore thorough consideration. The speech continued to deal with the commercial treaties about to be concluded with foreign nations, and then proceeded to treat of the general international posittion, and of those trouble waters of diplomcy into which the Kaiser has made so many dramatic incursions. "in foreign policy the relations of the German Empire with all Powers are correect, and with most Powers are correct, and with most Powers they are good and friendly." The distinction, which has been seized with avidity by the German Press, is important; and the politicians have quickly applied it to France and ourselves by a process of elimination. In the remarka somewhat unusual one- on the internal affairs of Russia, it is speccifically stated that she is a "friendly neighbor." The Japanese are welcomed into the rank of the GreatPowers by an allusion to the "pacific mission of this highly gifted people," that recalls, although it is certainly not intended to, the action of Germany in stultifying the results of the Chino-Japanese War ten years ago. On neither of the late belligerents, then, can the Imperian distinction be fixed.

The United States must also be excused by a further sentence, although the impending commercial war and the general American dissatisfaction at what is alleged to be a wilful disregard of the Monroe doctrine, and the attempts of the State-aided shipping companies to obtain a footing in the West Indies, may lead to considerable coolness between the two nations. With Austria and Italy, as representing the second and third Powers of the Triple Alliance, relations must also be cordial: although it is freely admitted on all hands that the internal condition of the former, and the openly expressed discontent of the latter, with an Alliance that is " prejudices against the progress of German industry," alluded to by the Kaiser, can only point to England and France: and this is made clearer by a remark on the Moroccan question, on which matter, however, it is allowed that an understanding had been arrived at. While readily believing that "the peace of the German nation is a matter of sacred concern" to Willian the Second, we may still feel that in many ways his diplomacy had not tended to promote that belief among other peoples, and that especially, when he intervened in Morocco, the stop was mistimed.. Nobody wishes to settle affairs in which Germany is concerned without consulting her: but when a categorical declaration was made by the Imperial Chancellor that she acquiesced in the Anglo French Agreement, it was surely more than a little surprising, if a year afterwards Germany proceeded to sow strife. Everywhere outside the Empire it has been taken as an intimation that the Kaiser wished to disturb the cordiality between France and England: and the tone of the German Press, moderate and extreme alike, has done nothing to allay that suspicion.

A remark that "tendencies suppressed at one point may reappear at another" is frankly beyond our understanding, unless an interpretation is put upon it that we should be loth to adopt. The fact that Germany has refused to cooperate with Europe in the Macedonia imbroglio cannot be taken as a sign that another surprise is to be sprung upon her neighbours. The Great Powers of Europe are quite willing to work together with Germany for common ends, and to remain on good terms with her in those questions where Germany alone is legitimetly concerned. If the Emperor finds there is distrust, he would do well to look for its cause in the diplomatic methods he has seen fit to pursue. Distrust of the German people there in none; on the contrary, they are sincerely admired. Prejudice against, or rather jealousy, of their industrial progress is not much in evidence and most would take it as the truest compliment that could be paid to a rival. We can sincerely say that as regards political affairs, a good understanding with Germany is desired by other nations. The only reason that relations have become difficult is that considerable aggressiveness is apparent in the modern German outlook on "Welt Politik." With such an attitude, that is noticeable not only in utterances of University Professors, but in the tone a large portion of the Press, of a leading party in the State, and too often of the Emperor himself, it is scarcely wonderful if other nations are less friendly to Germany than they would be if they had no reason to think themselves threatened.Those are the only "signs of the times" that we can perceive: and when the Emperor suggests that unjust attacks are threatened, we can only suppose that either he is obsessed with unfounded suspicion of his neighbours or else that he is making a not particulary astute move to secure the passage of the Navy Bill.

div.head:
Prince Bulow's Speech
The Moroccoa Question

div.p: Reichstag- Prince von Bulow stated that Germany must be stong enough to hold her own without allies. As regards East Asia Germany's relations with Japan were good and friendly. He believed that the Japanese, who through their bravery and intelligence, had won a position among the Great Powers, were anxious to consolidate that position by a policy inpiring confidence. The Anglo Japanese treaty contains nothing contrary to Germany's aims. "We have," he continued, "striven for and desire the open door. The greatest possible guarantee of peace is the maintainence of the integrity and independence of Chine."

He further explained Germany's attitude in respect of Morocco. Germany had by treaty the right to be heard with regards to any reshaping of existing conditions in Morocco. He quoted his note of the 11th, April to Count Metternich, saying in this connection that if Germany quietly surrendered her rights in Morocco we should be encouraging onlookers to treat us with similar disregard in much greater questions. He concluded by denying that Germany was seeking an occasion to fall upon France.
(Reuter)

div.head:
Condition of Russia
Genral Sakharoff Killed

div.p: The "Daily Telegraph" learns from St. Petersburg that General Sakharoff, ex-Minister of War, has been killed by female revolutionist who fired three shots with a pistol. (R)
General Sakharoff has been killed by a woman. (Havas)
Grave disorders are taking place in the Transcaspian provinces; the troops are participating. (Reuter)
The withdrawals from the banks amount daily to 600,00 roubles. (Havas)

In view of the number of canidates for office, the forecasts as to the formation of the Cabinet are of the most varied character and altogether conjectural, but there is a growing belief that Sir Henry Cambell-Bannerman will eventually go to the House of Lords, leaving Mr. Asquith and Mr. Morley are mentioned for the Chancellorship of the Exchequer; the latter is also spoken of in connecction with the India Office.(Reuter)
The Senate has passed the Bill for the seperation of Church and State by 181 to 102 votes. (Reuter)

In view of the number of candidates for office, the forecasts as to the formation of the Cabinet are of the most varied character and altogether conjectural, but there is a growing belief that Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman will eventually go to the house of Lords, leaving Mr. Asquith to lead the Commons. The names of Mr. Asquith and Mr. Morley are mentioned for the Chancellorship of the Exchequer; the latter is also spoken of in connection with the India Office.

div.head:
THE MACEDONIAN QUESTION.
GERMANY'S VOLTE FACE.

div.p: Germany has changed her attitude with regard to the Power and the Porte. She now urges the former to accept the amendments proposed by the latter. This action is attributed to her desire to recover the favored position which she formerly occupied.
The Syrian Prince, for Alexandria, is ashore on a reef on the coast of Barbary. Assistance has been requisitioned from Malta.
Later.
The passengers of the Syrian Prince are being landed.
The Senate has passed the Bill for the separation of Church and State by 181 to 102 votes.
The imports for November show an increase of 2,476,088 and the exports £3,494,861, as compared with 1904.
New Forest Election. Mr. Compton, Unionist, 4,539. Sir R.H. Hobart, Liberal, 4,340.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The English mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 pm on Sunday.

div.head: New Bibby Liner.
div.p: Yesterday the new twin-screw Bibby liner, the Herefordshire, left the Mersey on her maiden trip to Egypt and the East.
Cable Ship.
The Eastern Telegraph Company's cableship Levant II. has arrived at Alexandria and is repairing the Alexandria-Port Said cable.
Merchant Seamen's Home.
The annual Christmas Tree entertainment at the Merchant Seamens' Home has been fixed to take place on Friday, 29th inst.
Nile Red-Sea Railway.
Owing to a misprint, the date of the opening of the Nile Red-Sea Railway was given yesterday sa the 27th January next, whereas it is the 29th January.

MM Tewfik Djehlan, Denis C. Claudianos, Sophianos Sophoanopoulos, and Mlle. Natalie Pisani, physicians, and Mmes. Ekatirini S. Papadam and Evanghelia Ghioni, midwives, have been authorized to practice in Egypt.
British Recreation Club.

Lord and Lady Cromer will be present at the Christmas Tree of the British Recreation Club on Saturday, 23rd instant. Her ladyship has kindly consented to distribute the toys to the children, for which liberal contribution has been made.
Sailors and Soldiers' Institute.

A magic lantern entertainment will be given by the Rev. J. H. Scott, R. N. (H.M.S. Carnarvon) at 8 pm on Saturday next. The views will include some of Athens and Egypt, some naval sketches, and some of a comic nature. Open to all.
Survey Department's Almanac.

This useful annual publication of the Survey Department has made its appearance for 1906, and contains a large amount of information not obtainable in any other work. An Arabic edition will be published on the 1st January, 1906, for the Mohomendan year, which commences on the 24th February.
Crime at Ghirgeh.

The enquiry into the circumstanced attending the fire which occurred a short time ago in Ghirgeh Markez, in which a woman was said to have been burned to death, has revealed the fact that the woman had been poisoned and that the house was set on fire in order to conceal the crime.
Khedivial Geographical Society.

The next meeting of the K.G.S. will be held tomorrow in the hall of the Mixed Courts, Cairo. The meeting will be a commemoration of Elisee Reclus, Savorgan De Brazza. Major Wissmann, and Baron von Richthofen. The speakers will be Bonola Bey (for Reclus), M. Bircher (for Wissmann and Richthofen), and Fourteen Bey (for Savorgnan de Brazza).
Murder at Alexandria.

A Greek youth, a hawker of cheeses, seventeen years of age, was selling his wares in Alexandria yesterday when he met a native, who asked him to sell him a bit of cheese for ten paras. The Greek refused the offer, so the native hit him with a swish he was carrying. Thereupon the Greek drew his knife and plunged it into the Arab's heart. Death was instantaneous. The murdered was arrested.
A Domestic Tragedy.

A married woman of Meit-Mubsin, in the Dakablieh province, fell in love with a young man of the same village and unsuccessfully tried to get rid of her husband in consequence. The latter received a number of communication that if he did not divorce his wife he would die. A few days ago the husband found that he had been poisoned, and before he died told the omdeh of these letters. The woman has been arrested.
After the Opera.

The New Khedivial Hotel was largely patronized last night by visitors to the opera for suppers. The Tzigane Band played during the supper, which was beautifully served. The management of the hotel begs to inform persons intending to have supper and dinner on opera nights that it is advisable to order beforehand, especially for next week, as there are a number of dinner parties to be given. The fixed prices are as follows: supper, P.T. 15; dinner, P.T. 30, and tea, P.T. 6.
Charity Fete.

The annual charity fete in aid of the Conference de St. Vincent de Paul will take place on Sunday next at St. Catherine's Cathedral, commencing at 11 am., when low mass will be celebrated. The sermon will be preached by Rev. Father Joseph Hardy, of Nantes, almoner of the College des Freres. M. E. Eeman, President of the Mixed Tribunal of 1st Instance, and M. A. L. Gorra, ex-manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, will make the collection on behalf of the charity, which is a very deserving one.
English Printers in Egypt.

Waterlow Brothers and Layton , Limited, one of the first English housed to open printing works in Egpt, are the well-known printers and stations who have carried on business is managed by the grandsons and great grandsons of the original founder, one of whom, Captain J.F. Waterlow, D.S.O., is spending some months in Egypt this winter in connection opening of their works at Alexandria. Waterlow Brothers and Layton, Limited, are contractors to the British Government and to many of the English and Colonial Railway Companies, and have a reputation for the highest quality of work.

div.head:
A PORT SAID NUISANCE.
CIRCULAR TO CAPTAINS.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
PORT SAID, Tuesday.

The steamer whistle in Port Said harbor has become such a nuisance, and so many complaints have been received, that Mr. D.A. Cameron, H.B.M.'s Consul-General, has addressed a circular to the captains of the British vessels, stating that "article 10, section 6, of the Suez Canal Company's regulations for navigation forbids master of vessels to sound their steam whistles in the ports of the Canal excepts as an alarm signal in case of serious danger. Of late, however, the abuse of the steam whistles by some masters of vessels, especially in calling for the pilot, has increased to such an extent that it has become an intolerable nuisance to the inhabitants of Port Said whose dwellings are on or near the main thoroughfare facing the harbor. I shall be extremely grateful if you will assist me in this matter by giving orders that the steam-whistle on your vessel is to be sounded in this harbor only as an alarm signal in case of danger, and that it is not to be sounded in order to a pilot."

A supply of these circulars has been given to the agents for delivery to the masters immediately ships arrive. It is to be hoped that this will decrease, if not entirely put a stop to one, of the biggest nuisance in Port Said.

div.head: NEW HOSPITALS FOR CAIRO.
div.p: The contract for the construction of the new Greek Hospital at Cairo has been awarded to M. Stylianidis, whose tender amounted to £9,364.

The property now occupied by the Austro-Hungarian Consul at Cairo has, we hear, been sold to the Greek community at Cairo and will be used as the site for the new hospital. The property changed hands at the price of £14,000.
A meeting will be held at the Oriental Club tomorrow to discuss the founding of a Syrian community and the heads and chief officer of the Syrian benevolent and charitable societies will be present.

div.head: THE NEW QUAYS LANDS.
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality has decided to sell from 100,000 to 800,000 pics of the new quay lands as soon as possible. The matter will be discussed at the next meeting of the Commission.

div.head: MINES INSPECTORATE.
div.p: Mr. Wells, Chief Inspector of Mines, has returned from a ten days' trip in the desert east of Edfou, and starts again on the 12th inst. in the company of Mr. Mitchell Iunes for another desert trip in the direction of the Red Sea. On his return he will visit the Western Oasis.

div.head: THE KISWET.
div.p: The "Kiswet" or Holy Carpet, will be removed on the 23rd inst. from the Citadel Mosque to the Mosque of Saldna El Hussein, in the presence of the Khedive, the Ministers, the ulema, and a number of notables. The Government Departments will be closed on that day in honor of the ceremony.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA ULEMA REPORT.
div.p: Sheikh Mohamed Shaker, president of the board of ulema of Alexandria, has recently published his annual report on the scholastic work of the ulema during the last year of the Hegira. The book gives full details of the studies in the mosques, the number of students, and the arrangements for studies which have been already adopted and which will be made in the new year. The board of ulema appears to have been very successful in the past year. Students from all the provinces of Egypt have enrolled themselves in the list of the students of the religious school, and those who continued their studies to the end of the year were 440 in number i.e., 133 Hansfieh, 315 Malkieh, and 92 Shafieh. The president remarks that the Hansfieh have only formed about 30 percent of the total number of the students; while they ought to be double that number for the Hansfieh alone have the privilege of holding the official positions of Cadi, Mufti, and Mudarris (professor) of the students who were successful in the last examination 80 percent were the 1st year, 90 percent of the 2nd, 92 percent of the 3rd, and 80 percent of the 4th year.

Several inspectors have been appointed by the board of ulema for the studentsm, and all the possible improvements either have been or will be made. The Khedive has graciously made a gift to the board of ulema of L.E. 100. It is intended to spend the money on books to be given as prizes to successful students.

div.head: JUDICIAL IMPARTIALITY.
div.p: A correspondent points out that the Ministry of Justice has been very careful in refraining from appointing judges to towns of which they are natives, with a single exception, at Assiout. Our correspondent goes on to state that in this case the judge does his best to be impartial, but owing to the fact, that he was born and bred in that town, it is most difficult for him to be scrupulously impartial, despite his best endeavours.

div.head: OPENING OF OPERA SEASON.
div.p: AIDA AT THE ZIZINIA.

The opening of the Alexandria opera season is to many an event so eagerly looked forward to, and so replete with glowing prospects, that it would seem hard to imagine how all these anticipations are to be realized. Nevertheless, we think we may safely say that last night's performance will go far to gratify the most ardent expectations. The selection of Aida for the first production of the season is in accordance with the time-honoured custom, and the enthusiasm this noble work always evokes raises ever-fresh monuments to the glorious memory of Verdi, affording at the same time a striking proof of public spirit, which, in so many other directions, is peculiarly scarce amongst these who have made Egypt the country of their adoption.

The first act of the opera serves chiefly as a sort of prologue or foretaste of the pleasures still to come; it elicited some good singing, notably Aida's and Radames solos, as well as that of the High Priest. AII. opened well with an unexceptionable rendering of Amneris' graceful melody with the support of the woman's chorus; while the passage between her and Aida came in for a full share of appreciation. The second scene of the act

went off with all the blaying glory of its clarions; and the triumphal marches were attacked with the vigour they demanded. The scene has little scope for individual efforts, if on excepts the entry of the captive Asmonaro, which, if well carried out, as it was his night, never fails to impart a note of tragedy to the surrounding jubilation. Throughout the act the orchestration was without blemish and we have nothing but praise for the judicious and skillful manner in which Sig. Zuccni brought this portion of his difficult task to a very successful termination, when it produced wild enthusiasm and numerous "calls." It is, of course, the third act which decides the issue of the opera, and last night's rendering of it was in every way equal to any of the best we have heard. In particular, Aida's pathetic aria "O mis patria mai pih ti riverdro" was charmingly sung and was encored by an enraptured audience; nor was the house less enthusiastic over the impassioned duet of Aida with Asmonaro, whose persuasion of his daughter to induce her lover into betrayal of his county was admirably put into execution. The succeeding duet of Aide and Ramades was not quite on a par with the previous one, but was very satisfactory. The plaintive and emotional music assigned to Amneris, during the first scene of Act IV., is eminently appropriate to the situation and was rendered with exquisite pathos. The scene of all, however, struck us as a little hard and wanting in sympathy.

The roles were all ably filled; that of Aida being taken by Signa. Giannina Russ, who sang with assurance, if not with distinction; her powerful soprano, though at times apt to grate a little, carries much expression and found full favor with its audience; while the fine melodious tones and sympathetic utterance of Signa. Blance Lavin de Cassas, an excellent Amneris, leaves us with a high opinion of her splendid vocal and dramatic gift. The Ramades of Signor Luigi Longobardi was energetic and stimulating, while the purity of his notes and his clearness of articulation are alike mark worthy. A fine spirited performance of Amonaro was given by Sig. Pasquole Amato, and the part of the High Priest was very well sung by Sig. Constantino Nicolay. Sig. Francesco Rusconi was satisfactory as the King.

Of the ballets, those of the second set pleased us better than that of the first, but none were especially noteworthy. The men's chorus was, as usual, superior to the women's and acquitted itself well in the last act.

The house, warm and responsive as ever, presented its usual brilliant aspect and was filled to its utmost confines. H.E. the Governor of Alexandria attended the performance. On the whole, after so eminently satisfactory a production, and with the near prospect of renewing acquaintance with Sig. Bellincioni, we look forward to a brilliant season with confidence and pleasure.

div.head: ANCIENT EGYPTIANS' COLOUR
div.p: An English physician named Scholes has written a book of over 400 pages to disprove the current view that the coloured races are essentially inferior socially and intellectually to the white races. He claims that the ancient Egyptians were of negro stock, that European civilization is of the comparatively mushroom growth, while the Egyptians and the other coloured races attained to a high degree of culture long before our ancestors emerged from semi-barbarism.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning, bound for Manchester.
The S.S. Kaffir Prince left Antwerp yesterday, and is due at Alexandria via Malta, on or about December 24.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Ehios sailed from Malta last night and is due here on Monday morning.

div.head: A REMARKABLE CRUISE.
div.p: The Navy Department of Washington has been informed that the charges of the Suez Canal Company for the passage through the Suez Canal of the floating dry dock built for the Philippines will be $20,000 or $45,000. This has caused the department to give favorable consideration to the Suez route, and preparations

now under way to tow the big dock around the world to the Asiatic station contemplate that route. Work is being hurried on the colliers Caesar and Brutus and the supply ship Glazier, which are being fitted with towing machinery that the state can be made in time to avoid storms that occur along the proposed routs. From America to Manilla Bay the distance is 14,000 miles. The tow-lines will be one and a half mile longs, and the crew will be quartered on the dock during one of the most remarkable cruises in modern times. It is hoped to make four miles hourly. A considerable crew is necessary on the dock to handle the towing lines and operate the pumps and electric contrivances for keeping the structure dry. They cannot steer the great hulk, which will be fitted with wireless apparatus, to summon help if necessary.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: A request was presented on Wednesday by the controllers of the Societe. Generale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, appointed under the concordat preventif, and by the Hon. A. J. Davey, administrator delegate, for permission to borrow the necessary sums for the expenses of the sugar season. Judge Tuck, in his capacity of Juge Commis, replied giving permission to the Sucreries Company to borrow the necessary sums form the Daira Sanieh Comapnay at 5 per cent, and ordering an account and explanation of the sums expended to be certified by the controllers and handed to the Juge Commis at the end of every week as long as the concordat preventif remains in force.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive attended prayer at the Mosque of Saida Z nab this morning. At 3 pm be will preside over the solemn ceremony of the investiture of the new Guard Mufi of Egypt, at which a number of the ulema and the principal Moslem religious dignitaries will attend.
At 10 am on the 23rd inst. the Khedive will attend at the interesting ceremony of the transfer of the Holy Carpet to the Mosque of Saidna Hussein.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: An Arabic daily newspaper, published at Alexandria, stated yesterday that at the Government has warned Mustapha Pasha Kamel, the editor of "Al Lewa" that if he continues to stir up popular passions, his newspaper will be suppressed.

div.head: THE MEHKEMEH ENQUIRY.
div.p: The court of enquiry into the conduct of Judge Abou Khatoua, of the Mehkemeh Sharieh, will be composed of Ibrahim Fouad Pasha, Minister of Justice, Sheikh el Bakri el-Sedfi, Grand Mufti of Egypt, and Sheikh Mohamed el Gazari, of the Mehkemeh. The charge is that the judge destroyed a receipt of L.E. 4 which had been presented to him with a request for payment.
The accused judge was the president of the Mehkemeh Sharieh Court which gave judgement in the case of Sheikh Aly Youssef and the lady Saddat.

div.head: THE GABBARI TOMB.
div.p: WORTH PRESERVING.

The Alexandria Archaeological Society will meet tomorrow to consider what measures should be taken to induce the Government to preserve the newly found tomb at Gabbari, as Dr. Beccia, the conservator of the Museum, considered that it is decidedly worth preservation.

div.head: ASSOUAN NOTES.
div.p: Owning to the delightful weather the hotels at Assouan are filling rapidly, and there are already over 100 guests at the Cataract, about twice as many as last season this time.
His Royal Highness Prince Leopold of Battenberg is expected at the Cataract Hotel on Sunday next for a short stay, before going to Khartoum.

div.head: A GREAT EXPLORER.
div.p: Count Teleki, who is staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, belongs to one of the oldest Hungarian families and is a mighty hunter. He has also won fame as an explorer, being the discoverer of the great Bass Narok or Rudolf Lake, over 100 miles in length and more than 30 in breadth, and the smaller but still considerable salt lake which he named Lake Stefanie, after the wife of the unfortunate Crown Prince of Austria, now the Countess Lonyay. The expedition was attended by great hardships. In the Kikuysi country Count Teleki and his companion, Lieut. Von Hohnel, has to fight for their food and then again nearly starved on their way back from the Turkana district to the south, while numerous exciting adventures with savages and wild beasts befell the intrepid explorers. They returned in safety, however, with a rich fund of geographical information and a splendid collection of trophies.

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: Rear Admiral the Hon Hedworth Lamnton and Sir George Warrender, Bart, will be entertained to an official banquet by H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky Govenor of Alexandria, on Monday next at the New Khedivial Hotel.
Brig General BuHock, C.B., commanding the Army of Occupation, comes down to Alexandria from Cairo on Sunday next.

The Vicomte de St. Exupery, M. and Mme Phillipe de Vilmorin, M Jean de Vilmorin, and M. JAcques de Dorlan are on their way out to Sudan, where they propose to visit the upper waters of the White Nile for a shooting trip.
Lady Bloomfield arrived at Mena House from Alexandria on Wednesday and intends making a long stay there. Mr. H. Massie Blomfield, of the Ministry of Finance, is also at Mena House Hotel.
Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., the well known author, is among the visitors staying at Shepeard's.
M. Jean Capart, Conservator of the Royal Museum of Brussels, is at the National Hotel. He has purchased from Government a fine mastaba tomb for his museum.
Mr. J. Offord, the well known archeologist, is at present visiting Cairo. He leaves for London next week and has under preparation several interesting arrticles dealing with recent finds in papyri.
Mrs. Lamb, a charming American visitor at Shepeard's, is the possessor of an unusually fine pair of ancient Roman gold bracelets which she wears upon occasion.
Mrs. H. Brooks is a season visitor to Egypt, and will soon start up country for the usual Nile trip collecting bits for her journal.
Our readers will be glad to hear that Mr. H.M. Anthony, head of Public Lands Department, has returned all the better for his enforced change.
Mr. K.G.V. Murray, attached to the service of the Assiout Berrage, has been appointed 1st class assistant inspecctor to the Department of Public Buildings.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: Speculation in Egypt in the Ptolemaic
div.p: Gambling in Produce Futures

th epublication of Ptolemaic and Roman papryi is proceeding space. In addition to volumes produced by the "Egypt Exploration Fund," the British an dBerlin Museums and those containing selections from the Austrian Archduke Rauier collection, others in private hands are now being edited, such as those in the possession of Lord Amherst, and now we welcome a little corpus of a collection acquired by M. Theordore Reinach in Egypt in 1902.

Although in it the literary fragments are few, and quite uninteresting the legal documents are numerous, in many cases excellently preserved and legible and most valuable for the study og Greco Egyptian Law. The volume in which these records are published is edited by M Reinsch with the assistance, for the Greek manuscripts, of M. Seymour de Ricci and for the Demotic ones of the Reinach papyri consist of a series of documents which; although acquired at Ashmunein, the ancient Hermopolis Magua, evidently originally came from Tehneh, the old Akoris. They almost all concern the family of a certain Dionysius, son of Kephalos. The majority of these papyri are engrossed in Greek, the minority in Demotic.

Akoris is referred to by the "Ravenna Geographer" and by Ptolemy. It is situated 11 kilometres from Minieh, 1,500 metres east of th eNile. That it and Tenueh are identical is proved by a late papyrus which nited the two names.

Ptolemy places it in the Kynopolite Nome, but all the new papyri speak of its being an Hermopolite town, from which it would appear that the Kynopolite Nome extended further to the south, in the time of Ptolemy and the extant geographers, than when the papyri were written.
With the exception of a citologos' receipts the whole of the Dionysius dossier from Akoris concerns himself or relatives.

Dionysius was a military cultivator of the royal demesue, not as were so many personages in the Petrie papyri and those found by M. Jorgues and others, a Klerouch or holder of territorial military fief. A basilikos georous farmed the royal land, rendering a portion of the arvest to the king's officials, retaining the remainder for his own support and for seed.

In addition to the areas Dionysius had to cultivate upon the above terms for the king, his accounts prove that he rented, or owned, several other pieces of ground. An important member of the family was Sarapeus, mother of Dionysius; she also bore the names Senebellou ad Demetra,, and appears in the documents as security for her son.

M. Reinach gives the geneology of the family as indicated by th epapyri, endeavoring to trace alliances between th eGreeks and the indigenous Egyptians. This part of the work is followed by a chronology of the contracts, which date from 143 to 103 BC.

The legal formulae in numerous contracts are interesting not only to jurists but to the "man in the street". The grain upon which loans were secured, or which, as is much more frequent, was sold upon credit, and remtted to the royal treasuries as rent, or tribute in kind had to be the product of the recent harvest, therefore fresh: it must be compant that is, as said in Manitoba today of "No. I hard" quality; and unmixedn namely with inerior grain.

The majority of loans are those of corn, which it would appear must have been dealt in speculatively as cotton futures are now, because instances of such advances are far too numerous to have arisen from necessity for obtaining grain for sowing( the dates also negative this in many cases) or for handing over to the state functionaries as quittance for obligations, which should have been paid out as result of the borrowers' own harvest. Doubtless however a man like Dionysius, if the price in autumn was high, would be tempted to sell all his harvest, hoping to buy back later on, after a fall, sufficient to pay his grain tribute and for seed, though a man of weaker financial position would be compelled at harvest time to render up his tithe by the collectors.

The loans are always repayable in kind, becoming due immediately upon the suceeding harvest, and the interest was 50%, also in kind. This appears axtortionate, but it must be remembered that borrowers were obtaining grain at the annual period of greatest scarcity, having, doubtless, waited until the last, in the hope of a more favorable turn of the market; and were conventing to repay in the month when, reaping just completed, it would be lowest price.

It would appear, however, there were some illegalities in the rate of interest wrung from borrowers, either in the 50% of which no mention is often made, or because even a higher rate was convenanted for, so often the interest is unspecified and it merely set forth that a loan od say, 30 artabas of wheat is to be ready in the next month Poyai, June-July. In being evident that the amount advanced in the case was only 20 artabas, or less, whereas the contrast was restored 30 and was so embodied in acceptances, herefore on maturity 50% at least would be paid up in advance for from 5-8 months.

In some cases those promissory notes which omit the quantity payable accordingly augmented, of accomidation granted the previous year. Should the debtor fail to meet his obligation to pay in kind, contracts specify that immediately that permission is changed into monetary one which was compulsory and the creditor could enforcce a settleent in copper drachmas at the rate (mostly) of 3,000 drachmas per artaba. Sometimees, however only 2,000 are specified. There was no option, it being a penal clause. The lower rate may have been special to contracts between relatives, or friends, but it should be noted that in the second century BC the exchange rate between copper and silver drachas varied between 1-375 and 1-1500

The liability for a contract descended to the heirs of signatory, but its enforcement had to be placed in the hands of certain officials. The goods of the debtor could be reduced to slavery for his creditor's benefit.

One of these papyri expressed the fear of its writer that he might be condemned to servitude by what, he asserts, was a fraudulent clain of certain Lysikcrates. Thes person, one Kephalos, alleged that having bought some wine for 24 copper talents for which he agreed to pay at Sotion, the banker's, he did pay 13 talents of the amount and received back the "account of sale". Subsequently, he writes, he paid the balance and asked for a receipt but appears to have failed to obtain it( this looks suspicious). He, however, explains this neglect because "he had no idea Lysikcrates bore him any malice." The latter subsequently sent him before the strategos, of the nome, obtaining judgement for 10 talents. Why is was reduced does not appear, so it may be a scribal error, but the strategos permitted Kephalos 3 years for complete payment and no interest was added to the account, but he has to provide four sureties.

Lysekcrited, it would seem, not having been particularly triumphant in the litigation, handed over the new document to a third party against whom there could be no defence. Kephalos, foreseening probability of his defaulting some of the payments, in which case he says the amount of his liability would speedily be doubled, appeals to the king to annul the decision on the ground that in reality he had paid all the original sum.

One form of security is interesting. It is the guaranteeof a creditor's lands, but which surety is restricted to permitting the debtor to enter upon, and to cultivate them until the loan is repaid, but does not provide him power to become the permanent possesor, or even endow him with right of sale. Of course he would expect to reemburse himwelf to the full extent of the copper drachma rate of indebtedness, failure to fulfill the covenants of paying in kind at maturity having occurred.

Females could subscribe to or endorse, these contracts, and under the guarantee, or their Greek word. A widow had her son for that position and a wife her husband. The leader could enforce the contract against one or both of them and any other personnage who was also a security, and it would appear in any order or collectively as he might select.

M Reinach, appositely points out how clear a commentary this is upon the anecdote in J sephus concerning Joseph, son of Tobit, who when tenering to farm the Palestine ccustoms for Ptolemy. The king enquired what scuritye he should offer to him. Joseph, the Jew, replied, "yourself ad wife; each of you can guarate the impost accruing to the other."

As with the modern capitulations in Egypt there was a distinction between the judiciary competence in the case of contracts in question, in regard to whether they had been engrossed in Greek or Demotic.

If Demotic documents were in dispute, Egyptian judges decided according to Egyptian law (and probably precedents). A decree of Ptolemy Energetes, fortunately restored to us in the Tebtunis papyri. Sets forth that, if the contracts are in Demotic, Greeks ust abide by this. The parties, hoewever, were well protected because 6, and perhaps 12 witnesses were required by Egyptian law to such deeds. So that a Greek if he exercised ordinary precaution, could not allege that he misunderstood the important part of a Demotic contract. A breif approval of it in Greek by the handwriting og the party concerned is often endorsed upon the papyrus and its formula included the date and place of execcution. Contracts had to be registered at the proper town for the district. An Egyptian (Demotic) document was not invalidated by being registered in Greek but an Egyptian notary,"a preit of Thoth," had to be employed for the purpose.

The most complete contracts had the debtor's signature, the witnesses', the registration or officials's signature, then a docket summarising the deed, which came at the end of the papyrus when rolled up; attache to it were two strips or cords which were tied and sealed. The secimen copy was deposited with the official custodian, and if a dispute arose as to contract, this registrar's copy could have its seals broken and the summary be compared with the fuller internal engrossment, a similar plan to that adopted for cuneiform tablets in Assyria and Babylonia. The seal-, however, never appear to have been those of the parties concerned, as in Mesopotamia, but those of the notary only.
The description of various kinds of bureaux for registration in each nome for different documents has been attempted by Dr. Wessely.

The subject is completed by reference to what occurred when the contract was fulfilled- the title to everything hypothecated was restored to the debtor, and a formal receipt given. This it was wiser to have executed at the appointed nome capital for contracts and to be registered and signed by the bureau clerk. This, if he had really repaid his debt was what Kephalos should have obtained from Lysikcrates,
If the original creditor was dead his widow or heir had to deliver the receipt, which was termed greek word.
JOSEPH OFFORD

div.head: The Arab And The Desert
div.p: The author of this interesting work is at his best when tracing "the relation between desert scenery and the character of the desert people." Here is a passage which every one who spent even a few days and nights in the Sahara must feel to be profoundly true. Mr. Phillippe says:-

"What I came to feel more and more strongly as time went on was the extraordinarily stimulating and exciting effect of the desert and the desert climate on the one hand, and its entire lack of anything substantial and definite to think about and feed the mind on the other. The pureness and keenness of the air, and the wonderful brilliance of light in which you live, and which seems physically to invigorate and sustain you, enhance your consciousness and sharpen all your facculties. You see, hear, feel, move with an alertness quite new. Every sense is strung up, as it were, quicker, livelier, more express in its movements than heretofore.… And as you live amid these surroundings, this strung up feeling grows to tension and breeds a sharp excitement. At the same time all this extra vigilance is very ill requited. If a twig rattles, or a stone clicks in the sun, your ears shout the message to you as if it were a gun shot, but for the most part they live an idle life. Your glance rauges these wastes like a wild beast. It delights in its freedom and in its own movements. Yet all the time it is sending into the brain little news or none. In short, the stimulus that breathes in the air is addressed to the nerves and senses, not to the mind. It makes you feel intensely, but not think."
Mr. Phillipps finds in this quality of Sabara the secret of
THE ARAB TEMPERMENT
as revealed individually in the Arab as he knowns him, and collectively in the lessons of Arab achievement and Arab failure in the pages of history.

"I used to think that the temperament I read on the keen faces and glancing eyes under the burnous was the very temperment I felt in the blare and glare and breath of the desert. All around one here quivers the nervous excitability of which one sees so much in Arab doings- the nervous excitability which inspired all their conquests and campaigns; and invested them with their dangerous character of tremendous violence, suddenness and unexpecteddness... And accompnying this excessive excitability, which was the spirit in which the Arab worked, and the impulse which in old times drove him forth on his career of destruction, we have round us here, too, the sense of the profound limitation which undid all his work and led him back eventually to the desert again... What is it this landscape of restless sand lacks? The question brings us face to face with the ever lasting deficiency in Arab character and the Arab civilisation. It lacks the principle of cohesion which is the first condition of all prograssive development. So, I used to think, the strength and weakness of the Arab were alike displayed in the desert. All the influences that stimulated his nerves and starved his intellect were round there. In his successes- his frantic conquests and frantic art and science- is the stored up force of the ddesert's nervous energy. In the decline and disintegration of all his power and all his labour is the desert's fatal incoherence."

div.head: SAHARA DISENTEGRATION
div.p: Very interesting (Though not, of course, original, being merely a collation of the experience of previous observers) is the author's account of the work of physical disintegration and destruction upon which the ddesert is eternally engaged.

"The Sahara is not altogether the motionless, dead thing it looks. It is carrying on the work of destruction all the time. The means it employs are the sand itself, helped by heat and cold and wind. The variation oof temperature by day and night, often eighty or a hundred degrees, causes an expansion and contraction of the rocks so sudden as often to split them asunder as is a quarryman's hammer had done the work... Where this process stops, another begins. Apart from the newly split fragments, the common aspecct of the desert is a surface scattered with stones and pebbles worn as smooth and glossy as if they had laid for ages in the bed of a river. This smoothness is due to the sand, which works upon the broken fragments, rubbing and wearing them away... Moreover, the sand works not only on detached fragments, but on the permanent rock. The flanks of the cliffs near El Golea are worn and sculptured in some places to a mere lace work of stone.… Thus the hills and cliffs themselves yield by degrees to the sand's onset. The Sahara, it must be remembered, wears no covering of vegetation and earth stitched together by innumerable roots of plants and trees to protect it. It is open to all attack.."
THE FIGHT FOR LIFE

In some parts of the Sahara- their extent, Mr. Phillipps tells us, is estimates to be about a ninth of its whole area- the sand has already gained complete victory. In these parts, the regions of the dunes, all structureal form, represented by rock and stone, has disappeared, has been decmposed into grains of sand. The plateaux of tracts of firmer ground stand out, like islands, from the sea of sandand ever the sand gains upon them. The anther thus sums up the raison d'etre of the Shara:-

"In all this the object of the desert is clear enough. Its one endeavour is the destruction, blotting out, and utter docomposition of all organic forms. Every tiny oasis in the desert has to fight for its life. Each one stands a siege. Water, soil, a handful of palms give foothold for a little community. Individual property, social obligations, recognised responsibilities and laws, germinate and take root, keeping pace with the growth of plant and tree. But all around, constantly repulsed but constantly renewing the attack, the old blind monster fumbles and feels, like water round a ship, indomitable persistent, assiduous, hankering to get back its own."

We have quotedd enough, however to encourage the reader to follow Mr. Phillipps further in his own pages. His book shows a remarkable insight into the true inwardness and soul of things; it should be read by everyone who cares to know something of that grand and terrible work of nature which is the Sahara.

div.head: Irrigation Engineering
div.p: As Egypt's lean and ill-favored kine began to come up out of the river in th elow flood of 1839, and have come up yearly since till the full seven in complete with this year's poor flood, the Irrigation Department has had of late years a succession of short supplies to deal with. It has, therefore, gained much experience in the business of distributing water and getting the highest duty out of it. The conclusions arrived at as a resutl of such experience, are therefore worth noting, as the principles can be applied in any country, though the details of the arrangements would naturally have to be modified to suit other conditions of climate and crops. Egypt burrowed the idea of irrigation by rotation from India, where "Tatils" is the name by which the system is known. The same practice has been adopted in Java, and probably elsewhere. In Egypt it has been found most convenient, for the purpose of applying this method, to divide up each seperate canal system main canal and its branches into three sections or groups, which we will call A,B, and C. It has been ascertained by observation that the summer crops do well with one watering every eighteen days. Each section is in its turn given water for six days and is prevented from taking it for twelve. For such a programme to work, it is necessary that the relation between the croppedd area and the available discharge be such that the supply of water is sufficient for irrigating the whole area within the period of eighteen days. If it takes twenty-one days, one day's general stoppage is inserted between the working period of each section, if it takes twenty four days, two days general stoppage is inserted.

The general day's stoppages provide for the filing of the channels whose turn to take water comes next, so that the water may reach the tail ends of the sections, which thus obtain as good a supply from the commencement of their six days' period as the higher reaches. These stoppage days are also used to give water to those crops which have been badly supplied during their proper working period: The intermediate days of general stoppage provide a reserve which is utilised to prevet arrears accumulating to such an extent as to upset the published programmes and introduce confusion during the most critical period.

In the summer of 1900 the period between waterings had to be extended to twenty eight days. This necessitated a fresh subdivision of the system into four sections instead of three. Each section worked six days, and there was one day's general stoppage after each section's period, making in all twenty eight days. This was considered the extreme crops would bear, so that, if the supply was insufficient to effect the watering of all crops in twenty eigtht days, the crop area in excess of what could be watered in the time had to be left to its fate, as a preferable alternative to endangering the whole area of cultivvation. By means of the severe rotations adopted in 1900, and of other measures, the summer duty of water for the cotton crop was raised by one- third; one cubic metre discharge per second being made to do the irrigation of nearly 4,000 acres, instead of the normal 3,000.
It is of great importance to abide by the rotation programme, once it has been published. Alternations unsettle the farmers, and they do not know what to expect.

It was stated in one article of this series that when the period of distribution was discussed it would be explained how the summer discharge is controlled so that it may flow in channels adapted to a much larger supply without an inconviently low water surface. As the previous examples have been drawn from Egypt, it will be preferable to illustrate this point also in the same way. The principle of running he canals at high and low levels alternativly at all seasons is carried out in Egypt by the application of the three section rotation programme in summer for sake of economical and equal distribution, and in flood by the adoptiong of a two section arrangement, according to which half of the canals run full supply and half of them reduced supply for alternative weeks. In summer the total discharge required is 30 cubic metres a day per acre of crop, the crop area being 40 per cent. of the area commanded, or gross area. In flood the total discharge required is 25 cubic metres a day per acre of crop, the area being 100 per cent. of the area commanded. The calculation that follows is theoretical, and the figures arre not exactly those which a recent official note on the design of canal sections gives; but actual practice roughly agrees with the methos of reconciliation between summer and flood conditions, as will now be shown to be possible. Supposing a system to consist of six canals commanding equal areas, the summer programme would group these into three sections of two canals each, and the flood programme into two sections of three canals each. During summer rotation, the discharge is concentrated in two canals, and in flood in three. The summer discharge of 30 cubic metres a day per acre of 40 per cent of the area is equivilent to an allowance of 12 over the whole area commanded. When this is concentrated into a third of the canals the discharge is trebled and becomes 36. Similarly, in the case of the flood season, if the discharge of 25 cubic metres a day per acre of area commanded is conceentrated into half the canals, the discharge in them becomes 50.

div.p: A public drawing of £43,800 nominal capital of the Egyptian Guarnteed three per cent. Loan will take place at the offices of the Caisse de la Dette in Cairo, on Dec. 16, and the bonds so drawn will be payable on March 1, 1906, with the coupon then due.

div.head: To "Turn" Gibraltar
div.p: France has now in hand what, after Panama and Suez is undoubtedly the greatest maritime canal project of modern times, and one that in its political and strategical aspacts, probably ecclipses all others. It is known to Frenchmen as the canal of the two seas, and its object, stated in a sentence, is simply to "abolish" Gibraltar, or, in strict parlance, to "cunr" that fortress by means of a ship canal, navigable by war ships of the largest size, between Bordeaux and Toulon, thus letting the North Sea into the Mediterranean. Twice a Parliamentary committee has studied the question in all its aspects, has inspected British and German canals, and has had plans and estimates prepared. Up to the present no decisive action has been taken, but another great effort is going to be made to impel the Chambers to a decision.

div.head: Cyprus
div.p: The completiong of harbour improvements at Famagusta, of which official announcement is made, should impart a stimulus to industry and commerce throughout Cyprus. With a port sufficiently capacious to admit large steamers, and connected by railway with Nicosia, the capital, the only excuse for British indifference to the island as a market disappears. It remains to be seen, however, whether that indifference itself will equally vanish. The official report mentions, it is true, that the improved harbour is already being used by merchant steamers, but it omits to define their nationalities, their number and their individual tonnage. From the date of outtaking over the beautiful island, Famagusta has been intermittently patronised by comparatively small craft belonging to Mediterranean nations, especially Italian and French. But the British shipowner has not played the leading part in this commercial competition which he might have done, the assigned reason for his aloofness being the deficiency of harbour and wharfage accommodation for ocean going steamers. It may be hoped, therefore, that hiis energies and enterprise will now be roused. When Lord Beaconfield leased the island from the Porte his shrewd mind attachedd value to it, we may make sure, as market for British goods, as well as a place of arms commanding the Levantine and Egyptian littorals.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE.
Une interessante question de

principe Le Jage des Référés pant-il revenir sur une de ses décisions prises antérieurement, lorsqu'on élément nouveau se présente à BOD appréciation 1 ou bien faut-il, ane ordonnance qne fois rendue aur an adjet donné, exciper de la chose jagée, alors même que surgit un fait nonveau pouvant modifier la première manière de voir du Jage ?

L'affaire a été plaidée par Me. Manasardi pour les défendeurs et Mes: Roussos et Lazsris pour l'appelant, Aly pachs Fabmy. Nous ne suivrons pas les divers avocats dans le développement de leurs thèses respectives. Ce serait trop long.

Nous nous bornerons à faire l'historique sommaire des faits qui ont amené le conflit actuel. Aly pacha Fabmy avait acheté à Siouf de vastes étendues de terrain de personnes qui pour la plopart, parait-il, ne possédaient rien da toat. Il chargea de la prise de possession de ces terrains en huissier du tribunal mixte d'Alexandrie qui rencontra sur les lieux de l'opposition de la part de certains propriétaires.

L'huissier dat interrompre ses opérations et de retour à Alexandrie, il saisit de l'affaire le Juge des Référés. Les opposants n'ayant point fait valoir les motifs de leur revendication, le Jage ordonna a l'haissier de passer outre à l'opposition et de continuer les opérations. C'est alors que les revendiquants intentèrent une action en complainte contre le pacha qui, fort de son ordonnances voulut exécuter quand même. Mais le Jage des Référés, nouvellement saisi, ordonna cette fois de surgeoir à la mise en possession de pacba jusqu'à l'issue de
l'affsire portée au possessoire. | C'est donc l'appel formé par Aly pacha Fahmy contre cette ordonnance qui a été porté devant la Cour d'Appel Mixte.
